awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Intensive Research Experiences in Neuroscience (SIREN)
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Michigan (UM), located in Ann Arbor, MI, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. This Site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program. The scientific theme of the REU Site is interdisciplinary neuroscience, a hallmark of the UM Neuroscience Graduate Program. Participants will conduct independent research in one or more of the following subdisciplines: behavioral, cognitive, cell/molecular, developmental, sensory, translational, and computational neuroscience. In addition, students will engage in weekly workshops and journal clubs focused on current topics in neuroscience, research ethics, and research skills. Also, students will participate in a weekly improv course designed to build confidence, incorporate wit, and develop agility in public speaking. Eligible participants include undergraduate students who are U.S. citizens or permanent residents majoring in a STEM discipline. Priority will be given to students from disadvantaged backgrounds and underrepresented groups. The program also seeks to expand diversity and inclusion toward students with disabilities, and through a partnership with the National Technical Institute of the Deaf, encourages applications from deaf and hard-of-hearing students. Acceptance will be based on academic record, strength of recommendations, personal statements, and expression of a sincere interest in pursuing a research career.  All participants will receive housing, meal and travel allowances and a stipend.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn the fundamentals of scientific research through hands-on training, with the goal of presenting their results at scientific conferences. The coordinated workshops and innovative training exercises will prepare students for successful, long-term scientific career, both within and outside of academia.

The web-based assessment tool URSSA, used by all BIO-funded REU Site programs, will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Additional survey instruments will be used to evaluate program activities and track program alumni to assess retention in neuroscience and broader STEM disciplines. More information about the program is available by visiting: https://neuroscience.med.umich.edu/reu-site or by contacting the PI (Dr. R. Keith Duncan at rkduncan@umich.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Shelly Flagel at sflagel@umich.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site Summer Intensive Research Experiences in Neuroscience (SIREN) was conducted by the Neuroscience Graduate Program (NGP) at the University of Michigan, the longest free-standing interdisciplinary neuroscience graduate program in the United States. Program mentors were drawn from over 150 faculty affiliates across more than 20 university departments with active interdisciplinary research programs. Over 30 NGP faculty and 40 NGP graduate students were active in the program during the prior funding period. Our primary objective was to recruit, train, and equip students for graduate-level research and long-term careers in neuroscience with a special emphasis on diversifying the field by attracting applicants from historically marginalized groups. The training environment focused on rigorous research, transferable professional development, and intensive communication workshops using novel tools such as applied improvisation techniques. 

The REU Site began in 2018 and has hosted 26 participants with an additional cohort of 5 students in 2020 for a summer virtual professional development program in response to COVID19 campus closures. We sought to attract applicants and ultimately matriculate participants who had limited research experience or were from home institutions with limited neuroscience research resources and who contributed to program diversity in terms of race/ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, geography, socioeconomic background, ability status, and research interests. On average, we obtained approximately 225 applications per year (60% from underrepresented groups, 67% from women). Selected participants were largely from underrepresented groups (83%) with slightly more than half identifying as women (53%).  Program evaluations show consistently high degrees of satisfaction with mentor-mentee training and communication with particularly high scores associated with the amount of time spent with the mentor and the efficacy of an on-boarding mentoring agreement process. Participants also consistently indicated great gains in learning research skills and learning to think and work like a scientist. Students participate in three professional development events per week for each 10-week summer program, including Mondy Meetup Workshops, Applied Improv Workshops, and Breakfast & Brains Communication Lab. After every event, participants rate the efficacy of the event on a 5-point Likert scale and provide written evaluative feedback. In nearly 100 events over the lifetime of the award to date, about 95% were judged very-to-extremely effective. All participants gave both oral and poster presentations at the conclusion of the summer with many presenting their work at other national STEM conferences or regional conferences at their home institutions. For those students having completed their degrees at the time of this report, 85% entered STEM research fields: twelve as current Ph.D. students with six matriculating into the NGP at the University of Michigan.
